Epilogue

 

            Two months later, Alexandria stood in front of a full-length mirror, frowning. The dress her seamstresses had altered for her was beautiful. It was a full-length gown, a breathtaking jade that complimented both her skin tone and hazel eyes all at once. The neckline plunged to a level almost considered daring, but it suited her. The only touch to the otherwise plain gown was a gathering of the material in the front designed to accentuate her small waist.

 

            “Don’t pout,” someone said from behind her, and she whirled, startled. “Don’t fall either!”

 

            “Sebastian,” she said, relieved, then frowned. “I wasn’t pouting.”

 

            “Yes, you were,” he said easily. “About what?”

 

            Alexandria looked back into the mirror. “I wonder what my mother would say about all this…”

 

            “About me?” Sebastian asked, worried.

 

            “No,” the princess said affectionately. “She would have more than approved of you. I was talking about… everything else. I’ve met gods. I’ve traveled through forests half-naked.” Sebastian’s mouth twitched. “It’s not funny.”

 

            “Of course not.” He became serious. “I think she would have been very proud that you had matured into such a fine young woman.”

 

            “Am I truly worthy enough to wear this…?” she murmured, turning back to the mirror.

 

            “Was it hers…?”

 

            “The very one she wore on her coronation and wedding day.” Alexandria smiled dreamily. “I can almost imagine it. I’ve seen paintings of her in this dress, and I can just see how beautiful she must have looked, walking among the people.”

 

            “Just as you will. Perhaps we are making the coronation and wedding combination a tradition.” Sebastian kissed her gently on the cheek, and she felt the fine hairs on her neck rise.

 

            “Now now,” Marliana said loudly, appearing out of no where behind them both. “You’re not married yet, so I’d appreciate some distance from my princess.”

 

            Both prince and princess jumped apart, and the goddess laughed at their frightened expressions.

 

            “Did I mention ‘boo’?”

           

            “Marliana!” Alexandria cried in delight. She jumped into the goddess’ arms and hugged her, receiving a warm embrace in return.

 

            “Can’t you just use the door like a civilized person?” Lucas called from the hallway. He opened the door and smiled at both Sebastian and Alexandria, then tutted to Marliana. “It’s cruel to spoil such an intimate moment. Do you remember how mad you were when Guilino found us in that room off the side of the kitchens—“

 

            “Hush, you,” Marliana tugged on his hand. The princess noted the silly grin on her face. “It’s nearly time.”

 

***

 

            The ceremony flew by, and Alexandria could barely remember what the secretary of state said later. Her most vivid impressions were of the clear, blue sky that late summer day, nearly three years after the entire ordeal had begun. She could still feel the tight grip Sebastian kept on her hand as they said their vows, the blue-white their knuckles had turned before he realized it and loosened his grip, laughing. She remembered the way Marliana had stood in the first row, tears gathering in the corners of her eyes despite her stubborn declaration moments before that she wouldn’t cry. Lucas had only handed her a handkerchief, smiling a little, with that special light in his eyes that Alexandria knew was the deepest of affection.

 

            The people of Limodia who attended each received as a wedding present a small wish granted by any of the gods or goddesses who were in attendance. At first, the guests were leery to approach the fierce-looking Hawk, the silent Elk, and the gently smiling Caderyn. A small Rabbit, almost unnoticed, sat on the Stag’s back, content to watch the ceremony without comment.

 

            To the gods’ great amusement, the first Limodian citizen to ask for a wish was a small boy of about seven.

 

            “I want a pony,” he insisted to Marliana.

 

            “Why are you asking me?” she had demanded, scowling her darkest look at him. “Try the bird over there.” Guilino gave an indignant screech.

 

            Instead of backing down, the boy merely scowled in return and stomped his foot. “I want you to make me a pony!”

 

            “For the love of—“ Marliana had snarled, breaking off at a look from Lucas. Grumbling the entire time, she produced a brown, fat-bellied pony from the air. “Are you happy now?”

 

            “I want a black one,” the boy said sulkily.

 

            The goddess took a deep breath, and Alexandria shut her eyes, afraid to watch.

 

            “Here he is then,” She heard Marliana say gruffly. “Don’t break your arm falling off him.” The princess opened her eyes to her handing him the lead rope of the pony’s halter. After that, the crowd surged forward and asked for a multitude of items, their wishing ranging from the fixing of a broken arm to a wedding ring from the groom to his bride.

 

            After the wishes, a fantastic celebration began that ranged up and down the streets of the town, complete with open taverns and dancing. Evening fell, and Sebastian led a massive line of dancing people to a hall that had been cleared exactly for that purpose.  Alexandria had taken the opportunity to slip away.

 

            She made her way to the harbor, intent on a few moments of peace and quiet before she rejoined the festivities. The princess sat down, removed her slippers, then dangled her bare feet over the edge of the wooden pier. She felt contemplative, though not unhappily so.

 

            “And what are you doing, sneaking off on your own?”

 

            The princess nearly fell in, but Marliana swiftly caught her arm and tugged her back.

 

            “I think you have a death wish,” the goddess said, sitting beside her. “How many times will I have to save you?”

 

            “No more, I hope,” Alexandria answered, her lips curving up. It was dark enough to be officially named night now. She traced the familiar constellations that her father had shown her, mouthing their names, until she had found every one. “Marliana… what do you plan to do now?”

 

            “Sit for a bit. Watch the sea. It’s lovely at night,” the goddess said promptly.

 

            “No, I mean… what do you want to do from now on?”

 

            Marliana had known what she meant from the start. “Oh, you know,” she said as if she hadn’t a care in the world. “Settle down with Lucas in the gods’ realm. Raise a few demigods to carry on my name should something happen. Serve the One’s desires through the Voice.” She sounded enormously content, and Alexandria felt rather than imagined the flash of a large Panther lying beside her, tail twitching lazily, purring all the while. “Of course, I would like to find Emstur, eventually. I’ll let him hide a bit to make the end all that more satisfying.” She paused, then continued: “I imagine I won’t see you again for a while.”

 

            “No?” Alexandria asked, unable to keep the disappointment out of her voice.

 

            “No,” Marliana agreed. “I’ve interfered in your little human life enough for now. I have my own to carry on… or build up, if you will. I need to face down some deeds that I’m not proud of.” A few lines creased her forehead. “I need to learn how to accept my guilt and move past it.”

 

            “It’s strange,” Alexandria said casually. “I thought you hated humans… and me. Especially when I heard why you were being punished…”

 

            To her pleasant surprise, Marliana merely smiled. “Funny, isn’t it? Don’t think I’m going to turn into an all-around human-lover anytime soon though,” she added a little more seriously.

 

            “Never,” the princess promised.

 

            “Be proud of who you’ve become,” the goddess said suddenly. Alexandria looked up in bemusement. “When I met you, you were a spoiled, insignificant little cretin.”

 

            “Thank you…”

 

            “It’s the truth,” Marliana shrugged. “Now you’re… so much more mature.” She smiled softly. “I am very proud of the human you’ve become. You’re a good point in a filthy species.”

 

            Alexandria laughed. “So I’ve heard.”

 

            Marliana looked down into the water, the corners of her mouth relaxed and peaceful. Alexandria thought she looked old suddenly. It was something about the way her eyes moved past the stars’ reflection on the low tide, past the fish that swam around the wooden pilings, and gazed upon what was left. For the first time, Alexandria felt she might understand what it meant to live forever. Together they stared into the waves, watching the reflection of the stars on the water move with the swell of the current.

 

            Marliana spoke at last. “I have to leave now.”

 

            “Now?”

 

            “Now.” the goddess said gently. Alexandria felt her eyes burn suddenly as tears formed, and she threw herself sideways, hugging her friend around the middle. “Shhh,” Marliana shushed. “There’s no need for that. Besides,” she noted. “You’ll upset her.”

 

            “Her?” The princess was confused.

 

            Marliana lifted her hand from the girl’s shoulder and placed it instead, with deliberate tenderness, on the small swell beneath the dress’ decoration of material. Alexandria’s cheeks grew red. “She doesn’t like it when you fuss.”

 

            “I had the dress altered to hide her” the princess said anxiously. “I hope no one else noticed.”

 

            “Just me,” the goddess reassured her. “Just me.” She looked past Alexandria toward the town. “Sebastian’s coming this way.”

 

            The princess turned to look and watched the form of her new husband appear out of the dark. “Alexandria!” he exclaimed. “I’ve been looking everywhere for you. What are you doing out here by yourself?”

 

            “I’m not by myself, I—“ Her head turned slowly, trying to make the uncertain moment last, but even as she turned, she knew. The spot beside her was empty, devoid of the goddess who had so recently stared into the waves with her. “You’re here with me now,” Alexandria said to Sebastian, eyes fixed on the place where the waves hit the pier.

 

            “That’s true,” he answered. He walked out onto the dock and squatted next to her, looking out over the water. “The sea’s beautiful at night, isn’t it?”

 

            “Yes,” Alexandria said, startled into looking up.

 

             “Your people want to sing and dance in your name.” He smiled and took her hand. “Will you honor them as only their queen may?” The title sounded strange, but she could see how it could become comfortable someday, as familiar as ‘princess’ was to her now.

 

            “As long as you will do me the same honor, King Sebastian,” she replied grandly, using his hand to rise from the wooden surface. “Shall we?”

 

            “Let’s,” he answered, so gravely that she giggled until he grinned in response. They walked through the streets, hand in hand with fingers interlaced, and rejoined the celebrations as a joyful pair. Already, the people of Limodia were whispering that they had entered a new age of prosperity, of gods, and of happiness throughout the realm. The populace that celebrated that night had no idea how correct their predictions were to become, nor how close they would occasionally swing toward conflict with other provinces. On each occasion it seemed possible that violence might begin once again, the situation would be mysteriously diffused, or the leader would find himself suddenly disinterested in the tiny province of Limodia.

 

            And every night, the children and adults alike would pray to the true gods, the gods they had seen for themselves and believed in wholeheartedly.

 

            “Thank you for the pony, Marliana. He’s lazy, but I like him more than anything in the whole world.”

 

            “Dear Caderyn… please watch over my mother. She is growing older, and I fear a cold this winter would make it her last.”

 

            “Marliana, I know you can hear me. Come to visit when you feel the time is right… I have a beautiful daughter who I want you to meet. Sebastian is making a wonderful king, though he leaves most of Limdoia’s royal business to me—he can’t stomach the paperwork. The people love him… they have accepted us with open arms. We are so very, very happy, my friend... I can only hope you have found your peace as well. Give my best to Lucas and to the other gods.

 

            The sea looks beautiful tonight…”

 

***

Alexandria swam to the surface of consciousness in slow, lazy movements. She felt no rush to wake up. In fact, she half-considered sinking back into the comfortable bed that she lay in and sleeping forever. Were they at an inn? She couldn’t recall. The princess felt incredibly at peace.

 

            Eventually, her own thoughts stirred her into wakefulness, and Alexandria opened her eyes to an unfamiliar scene. She was staring at the ceiling of her mother’s and father’s room in their castle at Limodia. Had she been sick? Her recent memories felt blank, and as she tried to recall what had happened, she encountered nothing.

 

            Repressing no minute amount of panic, she bolted upright in the bed, scattering multiple pillows and stuffed animals that she hadn’t slept with since she was eight.

 

            At the foot of the bed, staring at her with her chin propped on her palms, was a woman with copper hair and eyes that were mostly green, a little hazel.

 

            The princess froze, unsure what it was about her that was so familiar…

 

            “Marliana?” she rasped, her throat unused to talking, and with that name, everything came back to her. The room tilted around her, but Marliana was there to lay her back onto the pillow.

           

            “Easy,” the woman warned, smoothing the bangs from her forehead. “You’ve had a rough time of it.”

 

            “Oh One,” Alexandria realized. She remembered everything now—the trial, the fighting, her interruption… and her death. “Oh no,” she said. “I died.”

 

            Marliana shrugged. “Not for long.” The princess gulped.

 

            “But wasn’t I…” she paused and tried to find a way to word it. “Wasn’t my body…”

 

            “… ripped up? Destroyed” Marliana suggested, and Alexandria winced, but that was exactly what she had meant to say. “Yes. I fixed you up though. You’re good as new, aren’t you? Anything hurt?” The woman looked helplessly anxious, as though she wasn’t sure what to do. She settled for handing Alexandria one of the stuffed animals she had knocked off the bed.

 

            “No, I don’t hurt” Alexandria said uneasily, taking the plaything and holding it close to her. “But how’d you do that? Put me back together, I mean. And if I was dead, how did you bring me back?”

 

            Marliana was silent for a moment, fiddling with the covers of the bed. “You were crushed with me in Emstur’s jaws,” she started. “That’s how you died, as you might remember. Before you did, you turned the key and freed me. I became Marliana again, killed Helki, and almost killed Emstur. But Lucas said something that made me stop.”

 

            “He made you realize that you’re the better person?” Alexandria pressed hopefully.

 

            Marliana eyed her as if she were still an invalid. “No, he told me that it wouldn’t bring you back.”

 

            “Why would you care about that?” The princess blinked. “You’re free. I’m not your responsibility anymore.”

 

            “So what?” Marliana said carelessly. “Maybe I like you alive.”

 

            Alexandria refused to be distracted. “How did you get me back?” she asked again.

 

            Marliana stood up from the bed and walked over to the window, looking out it. “I really, really wanted to,” she said finally. “I wanted it, more than anything. And I’ve wanted things before,” she added. Alexandria knew her gaze rested on nothing that physically existed outside the window. “I’ve wanted so many things—jewels, lovers, all sorts of guilty pleasures. But your… death…” She leaned out the window and took a deep breath of fresh air. “I wanted to undo that moment more than I’ve wanted anything else in my life. And then, I could.”

 

            Alexandria blinked. “Just like that?”

 

            “My theory is that the One heard me and let me get what I wanted.” Marliana’s eyes refocused to a point on the streets below. Alexandria could hear life going on outside as though it were a normal day. “It wasn’t easy,” she admitted without elaboration. Alexandria desperately wanted to hear how they had restored her, but she knew better than to ask.

 

            “Through that ordeal… Lucas and I were made gods,” Marliana said simply. “Well, Lucas was already a god. But he gained a great deal of power, as did I, and now there’s one more on the Voice.”

 

            “That’s wonderful. Marliana…” the princess hesitated in a small voice. The goddess turned to look at her, and Alexandria quickly looked down. Looking into her face now felt as though she were staring directly at the sun, and she took a moment to adjust. “I’m sorry that I didn’t tell you I had the key to your collar. I feel like I could have avoided so much…”

 

            Marliana shook her head, dismissing the girl’s fears. “You had to wait. I’m wiser now than when I was then. I’m different than I was as halves, or even as a whole soul before I was split. Got this great big ring to wear around now as my source.” She proudly showed off the item, and Alexandria admired the emerald.

 

            “You look beautiful,” the princess said honestly. The goddess had a certain energetic aura about her that she’d never had before. It constantly reminded Alexandria that she was vibrantly, exuberantly alive. The princess curled her fingers, feeling the tingling in them.“But… which are you? Lana or Mari? Which side won out?”

 

            Marliana gave her an amused look. “They’re both here. They’re both me. It was never a battle of good versus evil… though I’ve certainly changed now.” The goddess frowned. “I don’t know if I like it.”

 

            “I like it fine,” called someone from outside the door. It opened a crack, and Lucas poked his head in. “Hello, Alexandria. How do you feel?”

 

            “Fine, thank you,” she said, sitting up straight in bed. “Do come in.” She grinned at him. “How does it feel to be a god on the Voice at last?”

 

            The Dog returned her smile. “Excellent.” He slipped an arm around Marliana, and she didn’t flinch. “Your people want you coronated, you know.”

 

            “What?” The princess was distracted by their slight intimacy.

 

            “Your people want you made queen of Limodia.”

 

            “But I’m not eighteen…”

 

            “Actually,” Marliana interrupted. “You are. You were in the Voice overnight. You missed about two years of this world.”

 

            Alexandria stared at her. “You’re joking.”

 

            “Surprise,” the goddess said cheerfully, taking Lucas’ hand in her own and stroking the back of it. “Don’t worry, nothing exciting happened. Your secretary of state took care of the affairs here until your return.”

 

            Another knock sounded at the door, and Lucas cocked his head. “Looks like we should be going.”

 

            “What—“ Sebastian entered the room.

 

            “Hello,” he said hesitantly.

 

            “Feel better, Alexandria,” Marliana said wickedly, taking the other god’s hand and leading him out the door. “Invite me to the coronation so I may bless it.” Lucas rolled his eyes and shut the door behind him.

 

            “How do you feel?” the prince asked softly, sitting beside her on the bed.

 

            “Fine,” she said. “Everyone keeps asking me. Did I really…?” She still couldn’t believe it.

 

             Sebastian took her hand as if to reassure himself that she was alive at this very moment. “Yes. You did.” He wanted to tell her what it was like, to see her crushed in pieces, how much it had killed him, that he had slain his brother, but his throat closed up.

 

            She swallowed. “What happened to Claudius?” The feeling of dread that trickled down her spine gave her warning, but she was shocked all the same when he told her how the prince had died. “You did what you had to,” she told him, taking his hand in both of hers. “And now you’ve regained your kingdom, haven’t you?” Alexandria trailed off at the question, staring into her lap.

 

            “What is it?”

 

            She looked up. He was startled to see something akin to fear in her eyes. “Do you think I can be queen?”

 

            He smiled and squeezed her hand. A chuckle escaped him. “After all that you’ve been through, ruling a kingdom will be a piece of crumb cake,” he told her. “I think you’ll make a wonderful queen. Remember that your people love you and will be patient.” She stared at him as if to be sure he was speaking truthfully, and the old possessiveness rose up inside him, until he had to turn away.

 

            “I was thinking…” Sebastian said slowly, all charm gone. It was awkward suddenly, and he wouldn’t meet her eyes. “I know we haven’t known each other long…” His courage faltered.

 

            “Yes?” she asked, puzzled. “We’ll stay in contact, obviously. You’re welcome to stay as long as you like while you sort out the throne situation in Drisden.”

 

            “That’s not what I meant,” he said. She noticed that his hand was perspiring slightly in hers. “I… I think we have a connection,” he blurted out. “I think we should… we should, you know,” he said weakly, and she stared at him, open-mouthed.

 

            “I know it was only recently that I didn’t have a kingdom. It’s shameful, perhaps, too shameful for a princess of Limodia,” he added quickly. “Everyone knows of my exile, and perhaps they won’t accept me when I return to Drisden, but I plan to hand off the throne to my cousin. I’m content to be a prince. And I won’t take you from your kingdom, of course it would be in your name—that is, if you agree—oh no,” he finished, his face an interesting mix of pale skin and a flush that ran from his ears to his neck. He dropped his eyes to the floor. “I’ve botched it.” Sebastian clung to her hand as though he thought it were the last time he would hold it.

 

            “Prince Sebastian of the Kingdom Drisden,” Alexandria said in an indescribable tone. He was afraid to look at her, but she tugged at his hand until he raised his chin. The look of wonder on her face combined with the amusement in her eyes was astonishingly beautiful.

 

            “Yes?” he asked hoarsely.

 

            “That,” the princess said slowly. “was the worst marriage proposal I’ve ever heard. And I’ve heard hundreds.”

 

            His face turned blank. “All right.” The answer was mechanic, and she realized she’d sent him into shock.

 

            “No,” she exclaimed. “I—“

 

            “It’s fine, you don’t have to explain.” He began to rise from the bed. “I think—“ Whatever he had thought was cut off when she tugged sharply on his arm, offsetting his balance and causing their lips to meet.

 

            At least, he blamed the fall.

 

            They were both breathing hard when they broke away, although the actual kiss hadn’t lasted more than a few seconds. “You think too much,” Alexandria said, her voice squeaking at the end. He grinned.

 

            “Then—“ She pounced on him again before he could finish, but he resisted and pulled away after a moment. “Then this is a yes, correct?”

 

            She rolled her eyes. “Oh, yes.”

 

            “Good,” he said feverishly, capturing her lips again.

 

            Marliana burst into the room, her abrupt entrance causing the two young humans to fling themselves apart. “Stop eating each other’s faces, you two,” she said gleefully. “Real dinner is being served in the Hall.”

 

            “Why, you—“ Alexandria bolted from the bed. She hesitated a little in her dash, unsure how the god would react. The old Mari would have seared her with a scorning glare and asked what she thought she was playing at. Lana would have smiled kindly to the princess and let herself to be caught.

 

            To her surprise, Marliana whooped with laughter and darted through the doorway. The princess broke into a sprint, grinning ear to ear and shrieking death threats as she chased the goddess down the stairs. Sebastian shook his head, smiling to himself and whistling a little as he followed at a walk, picking up the slippers Alexandria had discarded in her mad gallop.

 

            The old Alexandria, he had a feeling, would never have allowed herself to act with such disregard for dignity.

 

            He rather liked the change.

“Ready?” Marliana asked Lucas. She lowered the volume of her voice so that only he could hear. “You don’t have to come. I know it’s been hard on you with me so… different. And I don’t mean to imply—“

 

            “Relax,” Lucas answered. He wagged his tail, effectively smacking her in the side. “It’ll be like old times… maybe a little different. I don’t know if it’s just me, but going wherever we’re going, with you, feels right. I should come. Although Emstur’s getting away,” he added, eyes nothing the movement.

 

            She began to turn and look, then stopped. “I have a feeling this is a window of opportunity,” she said instead. “I won’t be able to retrieve Alexandria’s soul if I allow myself to be distracted now. Which means Emstur gets away…” The Panther gave a small growl of frustration. “I already know my decision. This is more important.”

 

            Already the Bear had disappeared from sight, apparently without the Voice or any of the demigods really noticing. It was Marliana’s fault, if you thought about it—she had just claimed she was going to bring back a soul.

 

            “What do you plan to do?” Lucas asked his friend.

           

            She was concentrating, tail twitching every now and then. “I plan to go in there and pull her out. Come closer,” she ordered, and he moved to stand directly beside her. Their fur brushed, and he caught a flash of something.

 

            “Wait—“ He pressed himself to her side, ignoring the overwhelming power and focusing on what stuck out to him. It was like a sixth sense. The world was tinted green, with the exception being two red areas. One of the areas was very close by while the other was by the wall… next to Alexandria. The Dog realized the correlation. The red ‘rips’ must be where the souls had left this world and gone to the next.

 

            Together, he and Marliana moved in unspoken agreement toward the rip next to Alexandria’s body. He carefully avoided looking at the congealed blood that pooled around her on the floor.

 

            The Panther tried to push her head through the rip, but it was too small. With a growl, she took an edge in her mouth and tried to enlarge it. Lucas latched onto the other edge, and they gradually ripped it open wider. Both felt the strange texture between their teeth—something that buzzed and grated their bones. They recognized the feeling as that of power that was enormously stronger than their own.

           

            Marliana passed through the gap first, stepping down onto something, evidently. Lucas followed, though he left his haunches outside the window. One could never be too careful.

 

            The world suddenly seemed clear again, with no tint, but the air smelled different to his keen nose. Actually… he wasn’t sure there was air. It didn’t matter for demigods or gods, but it was rather disorienting. There was no way he could sniff out Alexandria’s soul without air. Assuming a soul had a smell, that is.

 

            “We don’t have to go far,” Marliana said, stopping just inside the tear. She was speaking without words. It was dead silent in… wherever they were.

 

            Lucas saw something materialize dead-ahead. It was the wispy form of a person, floating mere inches above the ground. It was sexless, ageless, virtually faceless, but it had two dark shadows where eyes might be, and it was watching them.

 

            “A ghost,” the Dog said, feeling a flicker of fear.

 

            “A soul,” Marliana corrected. “There’s a difference.” She sniffed as though she could still smell something. “There’s going to be more. They can tell we’re here.” Three more appeared behind it, each looking the same as the first.

 

            “How can we tell which one’s Alexandria?” Lucas urged.

           

            “It’ll feel like her, I think,” Marliana answered. The uncertainty in her tone was not reassuring.

 

            “What do they want?” asked the Dog.          

 

            “They can’t do anything to us,” she said, knowing what he meant. “We have a soul inside us… it will protect us.”

 

            “Then why are they coming closer?”

 

            “Because we represent life, obviously,” Marliana noted. “I can’t smell anything here, really. I guess I’ll just try to get her attention… should she be able to hear me.”

           

            “As good a plan as any.”

 

            “Alexandria!” Mari yelled, and this time she tried to force it into the airless void. “Alexandria! Where are you?” She took a deep breath before she remembered it wasn’t possible and started again. “Alexandria! Alexandria of Limodia! Princess Alexandria! Come here right now!”

 

            “I doubt she’s willfully disobeying you,” Lucas said wryly. The souls around them were getting dense, as deep as five in some places, but they weren’t coming closer. Rather, they just gathered in a circle around the hole in their world where the front half of a Dog was sticking through and a Panther was calling loudly for Alexandria.

 

            Suddenly, the souls moved.

 

            “Marliana!” Lucas yelped, but she ignored him.

 

            “Alexandria!” she howled. “Alexandria! Princess Alexandria!”

 

            The souls were moving amongst themselves, though the Dog couldn’t tell whether it was in hunger, excitement, or terror. Eventually, six particular souls moved closer and rest drew back. All six looked exactly alike.

 

            “What’s this?” Marliana said, baffled. “All right, whichever of you is Alexandria, answer me by walking forward.”

 

            They each drew closer.

           

            Lucas understood. “They’re all Alexandria.”

 

            “What? Don’t be daft—“

 

            “They’re all named Alexandria.” He clarified. “It’s not an uncommon name. Thankfully, you did say ‘Princess Alexandria’ or we’d still have thousands of souls surrounding us.”

 

            Marliana swore loudly and glared at each of them. “Which of you is my Alexandria?”

 

            None made a movement.

 

            “Why aren’t they moving?” she demanded. “Does that mean my Alexandria’s not here?”

 

            Lucas had to work at keeping a deadpan expression and commenting on the ‘my’. “I think she is,” he said slowly.             “You don't like getting close to anyone.” Lana crossed an arm across the other's collarbone, lightly tracing it with her fingers. She pulled her close, and they could feel each other's hearts beating, an oddly comforting feeling. “Maybe you should start liking it.”

 

            “I can't.” Mari reached up and hugged the arms to her. “I'm not supposed to, and I don't know why I want to.”

 

            “Who says you're not supposed to?”

 

            “I do.”

 

            Lana smiled. “And suddenly you can't disobey what you say?”

 

            The corners of Mari's lips lifted despite herself. “Of course not.”

 

            Laughing, the blonde demi-god pulled her even closer.

 

            “I'm supposed to be the dark half,” Mari said, suddenly serious again. “I'm supposed to be everything you're not. You love, and I hate. That's how it goes.”

 

            “Maybe it doesn't have to go that way.”

 

            “Maybe,” Mari finally acknowledged.

 

            “Just stop lashing out at Alexandria,” Lana scolded her. “She's confused enough already.” She glanced at the sleeping princess, curled up in a ball on the floor. “Look how far she's come.”

 

            “Yes,” Mari said, almost fondly.

 

            They were silent for a moment, staring at Alexandria, who snored on unaware.

 

            “I found something on her,” Lana said suddenly.

 

            “Mm?”

 

            The blond produced the necklace from her pocket, being careful not to touch the lump of metal on the end.

 

            Mari frowned. “It’s rather hideous. I wouldn’t have expected that your tastes—“ She blinked at it. “Oh.”

 

            “It’s a good illusion, isn’t it?” Lana said grimly. “He must have planted it for her in the market. And that’s why she wouldn’t open the door.”

 

            “But now he’s put himself in a bad position indeed,” The dark-haired demi-god grinned. “We have the emblem of his power, just like before. Although now they have a tracer on us as well,” she added, frowning again. “Very clever.”

 

            “Let’s hang onto this,” Lana suggested. “Everyone this side of the universe knows we’re heading toward the Omen anyway. Besides, I think the necklace could come in handy.”

 

            “If Caderyn finds it on us—“

           

            “We’ll have an explanation.” The blond smiled deviously. “Won’t that be nice for a change?”

 

            “Extremely.”

 

            Lana flinched, her ear swiveling toward the door. Mari strained to listen. “What is it?”

 

            The blonde’s face was virtually emotionless as her ears listened to some far-off conversation. She turned to her comrade, blue eyes opening wide. “They've found us.”

Once the small leather bag had been recovered from Mari’s pocket, mysteriously enough, the trio left the woods and entered the outskirts of Drishden. It was late morning, and the market bustled with people swarming between the different stalls, arguing over prices and shouting wares for sale. There were all manners of skin color and hair here, and for once, neither Mari nor Lana stuck out as different. Mari was as dark as the black-skinned tribes to the south and Lana as fair as the fragile, white-skinned nobles to the north. Alexandria was somewhere in between and, for once, looked less like royalty than a mutt of two different cultures that made her slightly tan with fair skin.

 

            Not to mention the trousers, blouse, and short hair that made her status significantly lower. No one as much as looked at her, and although Alexandria knew that was a good thing, her pride bristled when someone brushed past her without acknowledgment or trod on her foot and didn’t apologize.

 

            You are not a princess, she tried to remind herself. You are now a street child who is very poor. So poor that her hair is this short… She brushed her new bangs out of her eyes, already annoyed with them.

 

            “Lana and I are going to buy some information,” Mari whispered from somewhere close to her ear. The demi-god’s breath blew softly on her neck, which felt strangely exposed from lack of hair. “Don’t get caught.”

 

            “I won’t,” Alexandria said aloud, turning to look indignantly at her. She found herself alone and blocking an annoyed crowd.

 

            “Move it, urchin!” a man in ornamental dress shouted, giving her a shove into a nearby table. Alexandria stumbled before drawing herself to her full height, opening her mouth to retort to him. Do you know who I am?! How dare you shove the princess of…

 

 Then she snapped it shut and hunched over, pretending to be oblivious, or at least if only to avoid a response. The man grunted in disgust, but strode on and left her alone.

 

            Frowning, the princess followed the surge of the crowd as it neared an open square that she assumed was the market’s center. She was interested to see a motley array of performers, including a juggler and someone inhaling fire. Perhaps it was a circus? She was tempted to go closer, but the urge to find a hat nagged her enough to veer from it.

 

            By circling the square a few times, she was able to find a specialty stall filled with hats. Alexandria reached for the nearest one to see how it would go with her short hair, but before she could touch it, her hand was slapped away.

 

            “I no serve customers like you!” the shop owner shouted from behind the stack of hats. “No money, no service!”

 

            “I have money!” Alexandria protested.

 

            “You?” The shopkeeper looked her incredulously. “Why you not buy food? You live well to be buying hat, yes?”

 

            The princess quickly noted the gap in her logic. “Uhhh… it’s a treat for me! I’ve been saving up coins for years.” She gave him a cheesey grin. “I started when I was 12.”

 

            “Really, really,” he said skeptically to her. “Let me see coins.”

 

            Alexandria produced the bag and allowed the man to feel its weight. He immediately became more friendly.

 

            “Shop as much as you like!” he cried. “I give you fair price, very good price. I no cheat you like man over there.” He stabbed a finger at a rival hat shop across the square.

 

            “He would cheat me?” Alexandria asked, worried. She picked up a small hat that fit snugly over her head and turned up the brim to look at him. “What do you mean, cheat?”

 

            “He take all your money, perhaps for one hat, overcherge,” the shopkeeper stumbled over the word in his agitation. “Bad man, very not trusted.”

 

            She admired the hat in a small, cracked looking glass hanging from the side of the stall. “I think I’ll take this one.”

 

            “You look very nice, yes!” The shopkeeper clapped his hands. “Very nice, like royalty. A princess!”

 

            Alexandria flinched at the word and hastily put the hat back. “Actually, I might need the money for food… I’m sorry to waste your time.” Her stomach was flipping inside her skin, and she swallowed hard, taking the money bag back. “I have to go.”

 

            “Wait, my price is very good!” the man protested as she began hurrying away. “I give you bargain, best bargain you find!”

 

            The princess stumbled around the corner of the market into an alleyway, brushing past people. “Excuse me, excuse me,” she murmured, temporarily forgetting her disguise. A ragamuffin would have never said ‘excuse me’, of course. At one point, a man bumped into her so hard that she fell to the cobblestones, muddying her trousers further.

 

            “Sorry,” he muttered, moving away with his hands stuffed in his pockets, and she only scowled, picking herself up without comment. She emerged from the alleyway into a more distant aisle of the market place and found herself relieved of her money pouch. Alexandria spun around to look for the man she had bumped into, but he was long gone.

 

            “Bugger,” she muttered, slumping to sit dejectedly next to a fruit stand. She could smell ripe, exotic fruits on the tray above her, fruits much different than the strawberries and blueberries she was sick of. Her mouth watered, but the huge, glowering man behind the fruit stand deterred her.

 

            A customer approached and began speaking with the fruit stand owner rapidly in a language Alexandria couldn’t identify, let alone understand, and she felt vaguely scared for the first time. She was alone in some strange town she didn’t even know the name of, she had no idea where Mari and Lana were, and they hadn’t even told her when she might see them again. How long could it take to get information? Was it an all night kind of thing? What if they were planning to leave her overnight here? Her eyes filled with panicked tears.

 

            She was distracted from her self-pity by a slight noise to the side of her. Looking up, she registered a man’s hand outstretched toward a piece of fruit. His dark brown hair, nearly black, hung over wide, slightly slanted eyes. One of them winked at her as she watched him.

 

            There was something strange about him, but Alexandria couldn’t place what it was until he casually lifted the piece of fruit from the stand and held it inside his sleeve. The shirt he was wearing and the breeches were of an incredibly fine material. There was no way someone on the street could have afforded them without saving for years, which she doubted he had. His dress was of royalty—perhaps he was a noble? It puzzled her why he felt the need to steal when he could probably buy the entire stall with his pocket change.

 

            The shopkeeper, still deep in discussion with the customer, failed to notice a second piece of fruit disappearing up the man’s other sleeve. To Alexandria’s surprise, the thief hesitated, then lobbed the second piece gently toward her. She caught it and regarded him in astonishment. “Eat well,” he whispered, his voice soft, but quite deep. He couldn't have been older than nineteen or twenty.

 

            “Hey!” the shopkeeper’s voice broke into the common language. Both the youth and Alexandria started, but the owner had focused all of his attention on the princess. She didn’t understand why until she realized she was still holding the fruit exactly where she had caught it. “I’ll have your hand off for that!”

 

            “S-sorry,” she stammered to him, throwing a terrified expression toward the noble. The princess lunged back into the alleyway, where she’d come from, but a rough hand caught her wrist smoothly. She twisted, breaking the grip, and whirled to kick the shopkeeper’s knee—only to find it was the man who had stopped her.

 

            “Follow my lead.” Those eyes, a mellow green, winked at her again, and he led her forcefully back to the stand from where the shopkeeper had rounded the edge of his stall to pursue her.

 

            “Grogan, what a delight to see you!” the thief exclaimed, taking the shopkeeper’s hand with his right and gripping Alexandria’s wrist with his left.

 

            “Lord Sebastian,” the man boomed suddenly, stopping in his tracks and blinking down at him. “I had expected you later this afternoon,” He squeezed the noble’s hand with a friendly smile, but frowned at Alexandria as she cowered beneath his glare. “And is this lass a friend of yours?”

 

            “I’m afraid to say that she is a slave of my family’s,” the lord sighed dramatically. “A little short on flour, too, if you catch my meaning.”

 

            Alexandria fumed silently, but pretended disinterest, glancing around as if she had no idea what was going on.

 

            Grogan nodded wisely, and then began smiling as he saw the lord reach for the money pouch encircling his waist, which looked heavy. “Aye… I suppose good slaves are hard to find these days.” The opening of the pouch faced toward Alexandria, and she blinked. It was filled with warped pieces of metal, which clanked almost inappropriately against the precious few gold pieces.

 

            The lord slipped the gold pieces so subtly to Grogan that Alexandria nearly missed it. “I will see you later, Grogan, more near my usual time.“

 

            “Ah, whenever you visit, I am pleased to see you, my lord.” The shopkeeper bowed. “And how is your... family?”

 

            Alexandria caught a strange glance pass over the young man's face that was somewhere between annoyance and bitterness. “Quite well, the last time I heard.”

 

            “I do wish you would return, my lord,” Grogan said. The two of them had seemed to forget that a slave was present. Then again, if she were truly a slave with addled wits, it didn't matter what she heard, now, did it?

 

            “It is impossible for me,” the youth answered after a pause in which his eyes passed over Alexandria. “I do not expect you to understand the circumstances, only to respect them.”

 

            “I always will, sir.” The shopkeeper gave a low bow. Alexandria wisely kept   silent. Inwardly, however, she was beyond confused. Before her was a lord (or was he?) who stole like a thief (or was that it?) and had a strangely intimate relationship with a commoner if 'lord' was truly his status. What was going on?

 

            “We will be off,” he said finally, clapping the seller on the back. “Again, I am very sorry for the inconvenience she has caused—“

 

            “Oh, no, my lord,” Grogan said hurriedly. “It was a delight to see you so unexpectedly. Please—“ He took five carefully-selected prime figs and bowed over them. “My compliments to you and your father.”

 

“Thank you,” the youth said graciously, taking the figs with a smile. “Good day.” He strode away from the fruit stand, dragging Alexandria behind him, until they turned the corner. He glanced about, then smiled at her. “Are you all right?”

 

            “I’m fine, thank you.” She brushed off all dirt possible without meeting his eyes, but didn’t miss the awkward pause. “What?” Alexandria looked up.

 

            “Where are you from?” he asked slowly. The green in his eyes flickered with interest.

 

            Alexandria quickly realized her position. “None of your business,” she said abruptly, changing into more of a nasally, lower class accent.

 

            He smirked. “Ah-ah-ah. You can’t fool me that easily. Your accent has already shown through.” He shook a finger teasingly. “Very careless of you to speak so clearly. Where are you from, good noble?” The smile on his face was infuriating.

 

            Alexandria stood stock-still, wondering how to make this less dangerous than it already was, before she turned her head. “Look, thanks for helping me out.” She held up the fruit wryly. “Even if it was your fault I got in. But I’m going my own way as of right now.” She began walking down the alley, determined to find Mari and Lana for lunch.

 

            “You owe me an answer,” he said quietly, so close to her ear that she flinched.

 

            “How do I owe you anything?” she demanded, temper flaring. “I barely know you.” Her eyes narrowed. “In fact, I don’t even know if I know what I think I know.”

 

            He didn’t bat an eye. “And what do you think you know?”

 

            Alexandria stared him in the eyes for the first time, examining their sincerity. “I think you act like a noble, but you’re not. I think, despite your clothing, you've lived on the street, if you aren't now.”

 

            “And I think you’re something more than a girl on the street, even without your accent.” He stared at her. “I think there’s a lot more to you than meets the eye.” He fed her a lazy half-smile. “Is that true?”

 

            “As true as anything I ‘know’ about you,” she said sweetly, and he laughed.

 

            “Why not eat lunch with me?” he said grandly. “We can be truly introduced over something filling.”

 

            “Me, eat lunch with you?,” Alexandria felt like giving a well-bred sniff, but opted for a glare instead. “Why should I bother?”

 

            “You owe me, remember.” the youth mused. “I may have gotten you into trouble, but I also got you out.”

 

            She scowled, not liking the debt between them, until he laughed again, offering his arm. “Come. I know a place where we can talk without being overheard.”

 

            “Are you paying?” she asked abruptly. Her eyes narrowed. “I mean, would you be paying for the meal, or would we back our way out of that one too? I saw your money pouch.”

 

            “Suspicious?” He smirked. “I promise an entirely legal lunch.”

 

            The princess hesitated, wondering who this youth was and why he wanted to speak with her. Did he realize who she was? She was worried that he did. And what would Mari and Lana say? Yet... she did have to eat lunch at some point. It didn't seem as though they'd be coming to collect her anytime soon either. This would be a good opportunity to show them she could take care of herself-- or at least, that she could find a gentleman willing to pay for her meal. She smirked. “All right,” Alexandria decided, placing her arm within his. “As long as it’s entirely legal. I like my hand.”

            Alexandria and the lord wound their way through the crowded establishment that the princess thought was a mix between a tavern and a classic bar. The main counter was filled, the raucous drunks loud and merry even though it was only noon. Shrieking laughter nearly burst Alexandria’s eardrums as she stumbled after the lord before her. He picked a booth near the back, where a number of shady characters were eating and drinking, talking in almost-silent tones or simply glowering at anyone who stared.

 

            Alexandria sat across from him, folding her arms primly, and tried to breathe normally. The smoke and stench of stale beer made it difficult enough without her anxiety.

 

            “We won’t be overheard here,” he said finally, looking around with apparent familiarity. “Everyone minds their own business because no one wants to know anyone else’s—information is dangerous.” He lounged back, completely at home.

 

            A busty waitress sauntered over to them, brushing curly ringlets out of her eyes. “What can I get you two?” Her voice was identical to the one Alexandria had tried to impersonate, and her companion smirked.

 

            “Two chicken dumplings,” he said curtly. “Make it snappy.”

 

            The princess thought his tone unbearably rude, but the waitress was evidently used to it.

 

            “Sure, honey. Gimme five minutes.” She strode away without a backward glance, and he switched his gaze to Alexandria.

 

            “Yes?” she asked after about a minute, vaguely annoyed.

 

            “Tell me about yourself.” It wasn’t a request, but more of an order, which she took personally.

 

            “The stranger will introduce himself first,” she replied coldly.

 

            “But we are both strangers,” he laughed. His eyes crinkled with amusement. “Well, as you please, then.

 

            “I am the prince of this town,” he announced first, and Alexandria must have looked doubtful, because he added, “One of the princes.” He grew serious, but she couldn't tell if it was genuine or an act. “My name truly is Sebastian.”

 

            “Supposing I believe your name,” she interrupted. “I hardly believe your royal status.” She tried to search his face. “Are you being completely honest?”

 

            “Truth is a very fickle thing,” he told her solemnly.

 

            “You mean fame.”

 

            “I mean what I said.” He smiled pleasantly. “I am a prince. How else could I be dressed so finely?” He indicated the clothing Alexandria had thought so out of place. “Everyone else is poor in this town… everyone but the royal family.” His green eyes darkened until they were almost brown. Sebastian didn’t seem happy about his family’s prosperity.

 

            “If you are a prince, why do you feel the need to steal?” she asked sharply. “If the people are so poor, why do you take from them? Where is your prosperity”

 

            He flushed slightly, but his voice was not angry when he spoke. “I took out of necessity.”

 

            “A few fruits?” Alexandria stared reprovingly at him. “You ought to be ashamed.” To her surprise, he smiled.

 

            “I ought to be very ashamed,” he agreed cheerfully. “But now—“ he looked suddenly very intent. “Tell me about yourself.”

 

            “I see no reason why I should,” the princess said, still wary. “You have obviously lied to me right now—“ he made a noise she could interpret as disbelief, but she carried on, “—and I am not even sure why I am speaking with you.”

 

            “Could it get you in trouble?” Sebastian pressed, and she smiled.

 

            “Wouldn’t you like to know.”

 

            The waitress came by with their dumplings on rough-hewn wooden plates, set them on the table without a word, and strode off. Alexandria blinked. “How rude…”

 

            “Where you come from, perhaps,” Sebastian mused, and she shifted uncomfortably.

           

            “Where does your curiosity come from?” she asked. “Why are you so interested?”

 

            He smirked. “Let’s say I know how to spot the value in things.”

 

            She was uncertain as to what he meant, but he gave an uncanny smile before digging into his dumpling with relish. He ate as though he hadn’t in weeks.

 

            Alexandria was much more dainty and took her time, using the crude fork provided to cut the meal into smaller bites.

 

            “Cultured,” he observed around a mouthful of hot chicken. Despite its messy presentation, the food was very good.

 

            “Unlike you,” she shot back after she had swallowed. “Your image as a prince is ruined.” Curious to see how he would react, she added, “Or do you always eat like such a dog?”

 

            “If I eat like a dog, you eat like a cat,” he answered smartly. “Very daintily, with poise and with precision.”

 

            She stared at him, wondering where he was going with this, and took a bite of dumpling from her fork.

 

            “And therefore, as one of the princes of this province, I name you Princess Cat.” He beamed at her as she nearly choked on her dumpling. “How do you like that?”

 

***

 

            Sebastian leaned forward on his elbows with the sharpest of glances as she attempted to swallow the mouthful of food whole.

 

            “Chew,” he admonished. “It can help.”

 

            The young woman across the table granted him a weak smile. “Chewing is good.” He was once again drawn to the way she spoke, the way she picked up her fork with grace and continued selecting delicately cut pieces.

 

            “Do you not like being called a princess?” he asked, eyebrows raised when she swallowed harder than necessary. “It was merely a compliment.”

 

            “Not to me,” she said evenly. He shrugged and took another bite himself, ignoring her look of distaste at his careless open mouth. Perhaps she knew some sort of princess in… wherever she was from.

 

            “I have told you who I am,” he pointed out helpfully. “Why not explain yourself?” He phrased it as a question because she had blown up before at his inadvertent command; obviously, she was not a maid or anyone used to taking orders. Who was she? He found her curiouser and curiouser.

 

            She had caught his attention as she sat at the base of the fruit stand. This in itself was not uncommon; Voice knew how many orphans collapsed and died in the Main Square every day. No, what had been different about the girl was her expression. It was far from the hardened, emotionless shell of the typical street child, the cold exterior that was not melted by hard weather, extreme famine, or a mugger’s blows. The only time the mask gave way was when the child died.

 

            No, “Princess Cat”, as he had named her, was far from emotionless. Her expression at the very moment he had set eyes on her was tired, furious, and anxious all at once.

 

            Judging by the rigor with which she was eating, her tired eyes had been due to hunger—but not extreme. He had discreetly examined her figure, as closely as was possible through the loose shirt and trousers. It was well-filled and her ribs did not poke through her shirt. Her breasts, while not overly large—he almost felt himself flush—seemed certainly well-endowed from his daring glances. Starving women went physically flat.

 

            At the same time, he had noted her strong calves, which occasionally flashed teasingly at him from the bottom of her trouser cuff. She had tied them up because of the heat, and thinking of it now, he really did blush. Seeing her leg was overly personal… she wasn’t a simple street orphan. She was a person in society, this he was certain of, and such people did not reveal their legs. Normally because their legs were not very attractive. Face it, their carriage drove them everywhere. Where would they be walking to and develop such muscles? “Princess Cat” had been on a long journey.

 

            Everything he had noted had been in a single glance, and his attention had been captured not only because of her looks—which were quite good, actually. She had stuck out to him… as a recently-made thief (yes, he would admit to such a title), he had learned to trust his instincts, and right now they were whispering, “She is valuable. This is a gold piece among copper, and you must possess her.” Sebastian was obeying.

 

            Now, approximately an hour after his first spark of interest, she was more fascinating still.

 

            “Explain myself?” she mused finally, sitting back from her empty plate.

 

            “In my country—“ She had deliberately left it ambiguous. “—I am a maid in the king’s castle.” Her face was perfectly serious, but he didn’t believe her.

 

            “Liar.”

 

            Her face flushed angrily. It was such raw emotion that he smiled, which infuriated her more. “If you can lie, I can too!”

 

            “So you did lie.”

 

            The girl across from him suddenly stood up and began marching away.

 

            “Hey!” he called, his voice slightly panicked. The gold piece, the gold piece!

 

            “Thank you for lunch!” she shouted over the din, but she didn’t stop walking.

 

            Cursing under his breath, he threw two metal pieces on the table for the waitress to hear before rushing after her.

 

            “Look, what is so personal about your name?” he said, frustrated.

 

            “I believe I have had lunch with you, and my debt is settled,” she replied without breaking stride. Sebastian followed her, brain spinning in furious cycles.

 

            “If I promised that I am not out to harm you, not out to—know who you truly are, in connection with a princess or not—“ she stiffened, almost tripping as she exited the tavern. “—would you tell me your name?”

 

            “You don’t know the circumstances!” She spun to face him, just as frustrated as he was. “I would tell you. There was a time when it would have been the first thing I told you. But not now. It’s just not possible. She would…” Shaking her head, the girl turned down an alleyway back toward the way they had come.

 

            “Wait--“ Before he could say more, a hand of darker skin tone than his own or hers slammed into his throat. He felt it pinching his windpipe exactly right, in a technique that he himself had used on more than one occasion.

 

            He hadn’t realized how much it hurt.

 

            Gasping, he pulled desperately at the hand, but its grip was like iron. His eyes focused on the hand and trailed up the lean arm to stare into a woman's grim eyes. He'd been expecting his brother, at the least-- who was this person?

           

            “Mari, he's a friend!” the girl said in alarm, tugging at her grip. “Let him down, he's a friend!”

 

            Sebastian was suddenly released, and he fell to his knees, coughing. He touched his throat and could already feel the bruise rising to the surface.

 

            “It's time to go,” Mari said, her voice rougher than usual. She sheathed a long knife that Sebastian had not even seen out.

 

            The young man sprawled at her feet raised his head to look unsteadily at them both.

 

            “Are you all right?” Alexandria asked anxiously. Her hand reached out to him hesitantly, almost touching the skin of his arm before she pulled back.

 

            “Now I know--” his voice was almost nonexistent, and he cleared his throat before trying again. “Now I know why you haven't told me your name... and who 'she' is...” He smiled painfully at her before the dark-skinned woman took ahold of her forearm.

 

            “Time to go,” she repeated with a tug that had the princess stumbling in the right direction.

 

            “Maybe we will meet again?” Sebastian tried, but they were already gone. The gold is gone, the gold is gone!   the voice inside him said urgently, and as he stared at the suddenly empty alley, he felt wholehearted disappointment. Drishden was a large town, a small city, technically. People disappeared both accidentally and purposefully every day, and there was no small town gossip to recover them. Once someone was gone from your sight... she might as well be lost forever.

The Omen was normally a very quiet place, and the hush of night made it even more so. Villagers dared not go near it, claiming it was bad luck, more because the king did not support it than their own natural fear. The pagan religion had always been the “devil”, persay, in the face of a fierce love of the king. When little children were tucked into bed, however, and grandparents said blessings over the supper table, it was not in the name of the king.

 

“With the blessing of the Voice, we celebrate the meat, the bread, and the wine at this table and pray for health and happiness to continue in our home.”

 

“May the Voice watch over us and guide us in times of uncertainty. May the grass grow evenly on the Omen and bring prosperous times to us all.”

 

“Please have the Voice watch over my mum. She has a cold and I want her to get better in time for the festival in three days time. She has been looking forward to it all year…”

 

The voices whispered through the trees, creating a constant backdrop of murmurs to the clearing.

 

The Omen itself was not as decorative and pompously ceremonial as pagan worship sites tend to be. It consisted of two stones bigger than any villager’s house in a large, rounded clearing. One of the stones was broader than the other, at least a man’s height tall and long like a tribunal table. The second stone was smaller, but squatter, and crouched a short distance from its partner.

 

Both slabs glowed white as bone from the almost-full moon overhead.

 

Now two figures broke from the trees encircling the clearing, discussing something in low voices.

 

“I don’t believe you.” Guilino flapped his wings. “Now that I think about it, you’ve always followed Marliana around like a lapdog—no offense.” His talons reflexively gripped the short, dark fur of the Dog tighter.

 

“Ouch,” Lucas complained. “I do not follow her around. I agree with her on many things but not because it’s her.”

 

They approached the larger of the two stones, and Lucas promptly sat down beside it. Guilino flapped awkwardly to keep his balance, landing with annoyance on the ground. “You don’t have to be so rude about it. I’m not saying it’s a bad thing.”

 

The Dog’s ears rested flat against his head sullenly. Guilino grumbled something under his breath, the words “foolish” and “young love” the only coherent items, and rose with minor difficulty to perch on top of the large stone.

 

Two more figures suddenly melted from the treeline. Lucas’ tail thumped as he recognized them. “Caderyn! Numino!” he called softly.

The fair-haired woman in front of them winced at her bluntness. “If she didn’t know before, she knows now,” she commented.

 

      “He… what.” Alexandria ended. She had stopped walking in her tracks, and Mari halted behind her.

“You’re safe now,” the woman reassured her.

“At first, the One considered the people just like any other animal. They ate like other animals. They swam like other animals. Perhaps the only thing that was interesting about them was that they walked on two legs rather than four.

A few of the animals were also gifted beyond the normal limitations of their race and knew the One well. If the crops were too scant, the One would direct through the Voice where the people and animals would find enough food for the winter. Mari led the way, her glinting eyes discouraging any would-be thieves, and as Alexandria was walking, she suddenly realized she was very tired.

            Lana groaned, and her thoughts were easily read without touch. “You would fall with more force,” Mari said cheerfully. “You weigh more.”

            “I still mourn for him, of course.” Alexandria frowned. “It’s been fifteen days... fifteen days since he still walked this world,” her tone grew softer, “alive and unharmed... what I would give to have his counsel now.” She faltered, staring off into space, and in the silence there was a low tramping of feet growing ever louder.

 

            “Milady?” Hattie asked anxiously as Alexandria’s head turned to the door.

 

            “Grab the bed,” she commanded, leaping up to go to it.

 

            “What?”

 

            “Now!” Alexandria was trying to heave the heavy bed frame herself, but it wasn’t moving. Together, the two girls were able to slide the bed in front of the door.

 

            “But it’s locked,” Hattie protested feebly. “Why does milady need such privacy?”

 

            “It’s not for privacy,” the princess panted, pulling a dresser to tip onto the bed. “It’s for our protection. Both yours and mine, Hattie.”

            The girl unlocked the door with a further word, dropped the key for Alexandria, and dashed into the recesses of the castle.

 

            “You’re welcome,” the princess muttered. So much for her loyal handmaiden. Weren’t they supposed to remain by royalty’s side in times of war? Alexandria left the main door for a moment to securely lock the servant’s entrance again and pocket the key. What a joke that had been... she glanced around fearfully, aware that the feet were a mere corridor away from the door. What should she do?

 

            She might refuse to open it and have it busted down in time. Or she could simply unlock everything and let whoever it was come. She wasn’t sure just who that someone was, but if Mari was terrified, so was she. Unable to imagine who it might be, Alexandria sat on the bed and mused. She couldn’t understand why Mari would urge her to lock the door as she had... she could only suppose that Bryson really was leader of the pirates, she joked to herself, a goofy smile creeping over her face.

 

            Alexandria’s eyes widened. Suppose he actually did have pirates on his side. Real live pirates! How exiting that would be... secretly, she had always wanted to meet a pirate. She had always thought they couldn’t possibly be as vulgar as people made them out to be.

 

Her thoughts drifted to the window again and what she could see of the docks where she had been captured. Her mind slowly made the connection. She had been captured and taken to a dock... with a filthy man in an eye-patch... who had laughed when she threatened Bryson’s wrath on him. Could this mean...?

 

No. She didn’t know what it meant. Alexandria always hated to assume anything but the best in a person, and, rather subconsciously, she decided not to start now. That train of thought was slain as mercilessly as a monster.

 

A sudden rapping on the door made her gasp and spin to face it, a hand clasped to her breast. She could feel her heart pounding wildly, and she opened her mouth to speak.

 

“Princess?” a cry outside the door interrupted her half-formed words. She swallowed them and waited silently, not knowing what else to do. “Princess!” the call came again. The handle on the door shook, someone harping on it on the other side. “Princess Alexandria!”

 

She still did not answer. Her hand slid to her thigh instead and patted about vainly. Where was her dagger? If they did break in, she would...

 

A loud crash into the door made the lock blurt a sound not at all encouraging. “Princess?” the voice was worried. It occurred to her that perhaps she was overreacting... both she and Mari were overreacting?

 

Making up her mind at last, she called, “I’m- I’m not dressed. What is it?” The hammering on the door stopped.

 

“His highness the king formally requests your presence in the dining hall for lunch,” the voice announced. “Do you accept?”

 

“I’m not dressed,” she repeated, mind flailing for an excuse. “And I feel quite tired after this morning. Please make my excuses to him.”

 

“I’m afraid you’ll have to come down,” the voice replied calmly, in such a crisp tone that Alexandria suspected he was a soldier. That would explain the tramping of feet. He had probably brought a unit of underlings with him. “I was told to insist upon it.”

 

“I’m sorry,” she said, more coldly than before. “I will not come.”

 

“Then we must break in, princess,” the soldier replied calmly. He knew how shocking it would be for such news to escape, that soldiers had forcibly broken into the princess’s quarters, but he knew instinctively that to disobey Bryson would be far more dangerous. “Please stand clear of the door and dress yourself.”

 

On the other side of the door, Alexandria’s mouth opened and closed like a dying fish.

 

            The next crash was much more certain, as though they had been waiting for his command to attack the door more than halfheartedly. The lock strained, still holding, but Alexandria feared it would not withstand the assault much longer. Looking at the small pile of furniture, she felt helpless. She wished... who would save her? She didn’t know. Whom else did she trust? She had trusted her handmaiden... a mistake. She had trusted her father... and he was now dead. Who else? Her mother? Her mother had died not long after she was born.

 

            Her eyes filled with tears. Yes, she had read all those sappy modern novels, of true love and friendship overcoming all. Instead of true love, all she got were impatient suitors, men who were impossibly rich and sick of their wives, men who wanted to force her to accept the proposal not out of love for her, but out of love for her country’s worth... what had happened to hers?

 

            She sat down on the bed, ignoring the repeated attacks on the door, and only sobbing harder as the lock snapped. Even so, Alexandria braced her feet against the floor and hung on to the bed frame, shaking with it every time it shuddered from a blow. The door opened a crack, and she threw her weight against the backboard, closing it again. It would only be a few more minutes at most... she still wasn’t sure why she was holding it shut so stubbornly. Why had Mari made her do this again? Her mind was fuzzy on the subject, and she reached up a hand unconsciously to touch the necklace around her neck.

 

            The ugly metal nearly cut her hand, but she pulled some comfort from it as well as some confusing emotions. There was no reason she should do as Mari asked... there was no reason at all. She was the princess, now that she remembered it. She sat up a little straighter, aware that the banging had stopped.

 

            “Princess, will you come out?” the soldier’s voice called from the other side. She suddenly wanted... so very, very much... to join the king for lunch. What a pleasant thing... there would be a good amount of time to get to know the new king better. He was her uncle, and she didn’t know much beyond rumors, after all.

 

            She slowly rose from her position on the bed and began to answer, hands leaving the necklace to clasp together. “Yes, I do believe I-“

 

            “Don’t wring your hands like that,” a light voice chided from beyond her. “You’ll ruin your nice skin,”

 

            Alexandria shrieked, dropping the necklace back into her dress, and turned in one movement to face a shocking sight. Lana stood before her, a cheery smile on her face, and behind her was Mari, naked as the day she’d been born. The dark-haired woman stared at her, an amused look crossing her face. “Like what you s-“ she began to ask, but Lana elbowed her in the stomach.

 

            “How’s the fort-holding going?” she asked the still shell-shocked princess. “Seems you’ve done all right so far.” She inspected the bed frame, the smile on her face spreading wider. “What were you going to do? Attack them with pillows?”

 

            “No!” Alexandria blurted out, then covered her mouth. Of all the questions that had burst into her mind, why had she answered that one?

 

            Lana laughed in response, and Mari began nonchalantly to dress herself in her standard outfit of breeches and a loose-fitting shirt.

 

            “What—how did you get in?” the princess asked finally. “The doors are locked... though not this one anymore.” She glanced to the main door.

 

            “Magic,” Lana tossed the answer out carelessly enough, but Alexandria remembered the man’s words clearly enough.

 

‘These slaves are magic!’  he had insisted. ‘Accept them into your service and you will find you no longer need guards.’

 

The princess looked hard at the pair of slaves, who in turn stared patiently back at her.

 

The contest was interrupted only when the loud banging on the door resumed. “Princess? Who’s in there with you?”

 

Alexandria opened her mouth to answer, but Mari beat her to it.

 

“Piss off,” the slave said coolly. The princess stared at her in frank astonishment. “And do tell the king we won’t be coming for lunch.”

 

“That’s not a polite way to address royalty,” the crisp voice of Bryson informed her from outside the door. Alexandria stared at it. How long had he been there? “Let’s have lunch together.”

 

Mari quickly recovered stride. “If you think there’s any way in-“

 

“Wait,” Alexandria interrupted, stepping toward the door. One hand reached toward the handle, and her other clasped the chain around her neck. “I see no reason for remaining cooped up in here any longer than I have to,” she said in a strangely flat voice.

 

“Princess!” Lana objected, striding forward to block her way to the door. Mari suddenly glanced from the door to Alexandria, noting her confused expression. “Please don’t do this,” Lana continued. “Trust me, it would be much better to stay here.”

 

The girl merely shrugged her away. “I’m the princess here… and I would really like to go down for a nice lunch.”

 

“That’s the spirit!” praised Bryson, his voice only slightly muffled through the door. Lana visibly drooped. How could the princess trust him rather than her? They had proved their worth in rescuing her, hadn’t they?

 

As Alexandria moved the furniture away from the door, Mari calmly touched her companion on the wrist. Almost instantaneously, the blonde’s eyes narrowed, and she sucked in a sharp breath. That would explain it… but by how could he have gained power over her?

 

The princess suddenly paused and looked back to the two slaves. “Wait,” she cried, causing the soldiers and king to stare at her. “My slaves will come too.”

 

“Slaves at the royal table?” Bryson scoffed, his features twisting in anger. “I will not hear of it.”

 

“Then I won’t come.” Alexandria’s jaw was set in a stubborn line.

 

Her uncle cursed vehemently, pacing back and forth across the carpet before her chambers. She watched with frightened eyes as every step became more livid. “Fine,” he half-snarled.

 

                Lana quirked an eyebrow, then began walking with the rest of the company in silence to the dining room. Why, precisely, Bryson had a grudge against the princess had eluded her so far… it could be that he wanted to eradicate all hope for the townspeople. That was more his style than pure takeover. He was very much like a cat, taunting and torturing the poor vermin it had caught until the creature finally died.

 

                 But supposing his plan had been something akin the lines of eating alone with the princess in the dining room and slitting her throat, or even simply poisoning her, why had he allowed them to accompany her? Surely he realized they would test every morsel before it touched her lips, and as watchful as they were, he could not harm her.

 

                  She was thinking so determinedly, chewing her lip a little in preoccupation, that she would have walked into the doorframe of the room had Mari not tugged her sleeve just in time.

 

                  “Welcome to my Great Hall,” Bryson announced. With his usual big-headed pomp, Lana thought nastily. A servant rushed up to the king and bowed.

 

                    “Lunch is served.”

            “We would have,” Lana said apologetically. “But it’s already noon, and we hadn’t eaten since the day before. Mari visited the kitchen and brought these back. Now that you’re awake, however, what would you so desire?”

This pair didn’t feel like slaves at all… companions, more like, and it made her uneasy. How should she treat them? The man had called them slaves, but the document he had made out could have been forged. She would look them up in the records later.

 

            “Some toast and spread, please,” she said. “And a glass of orange juice.”

 

            Lana raised an eyebrow at Mari, who expelled a violent sigh before grabbing the tray and stalking out through the door.

            “No, no,” the blond-haired girl assured her. A grin stretched from ear to ear.

 

            “What then?” the princess demanded.

            Alexandria’s lips were trembling, and she turned away quickly.

 

            “I’m sorry,” Lana said, concerned. “I didn’t mean to upset you… princess?” She gently twisted the girl around to face her and stared in astonishment. Alexandria was laughing and trying not to snort, shoulders shaking. “You’re… laughing?”

 

            “A muffin-type princess?” she giggled. “And don’t you know, it’s not polite for a princess to laugh loudly. You have to make these tiny little bursts—“

 

            Lana burst out laughing herself, sending them both into hysterics.

 

            Mari chose that moment to return, entering the room with a wary gaze that swept back and forth as to determine what had set them off. She set down the tray of toast and glass of orange juice with a surprisingly agile flick of her hands. Then, withdrawing them into her cloak, she sat and waited for them to calm down.

 

            But now the princess and slave were beginning to cry from laughing so much, and she became annoyed. “What?” she grated out.

 

            “I—you—hahaha—oh, sorry—“ Lana fumbled helplessly, wiping a few tears from her eyes. “It’s only that we—a muffin-type, ahahaha—“

 

            Abruptly, Mari stood and stalked over to her twin, sweeping up her night sleeve and grabbing her arm roughly. Alexandria blinked at the whole person she saw; then they were once again two women staring at each other with unfocused eyes. Mari suddenly raised an eyebrow. “A muffin-type princess?”

 

            Lana snapped back into focus, giggling once more and grinning.

 

            “What just happened?” Alexandria said, looking from one to the other. “You were just… I just saw…” The two slaves were looking at her patiently, waiting. “Never mind… I think I need breakfast.”
