            In the morning, Alexandria had pleaded to be allowed into the public marketplace, insisting that she needed a new gown. Bryson had considered it, then allowed it under the one condition that she leave her slaves so as not to arouse suspicion and take a few undercover guards instead.

 

            Pouting, Alexandria had eventually agreed before returning to her quarters to fetch her purse.

 

            “Milady will not have us join her?” Lana’s brow furrowed, aghast. “You are easily recognizable clothed in that.”

 

            Alexandria flashed her a relaxed smile. “With all those guards, it won’t matter. And there are other women in mourning, you know.” She reached under her mattress and took out a small, golden pouch to hitch under her dress. It looked heavy, and Lana shifted uneasily.

 

            “Milady,” she stated seriously. “I have only known you yet a day, but I hardly think this is wise—“

 

            “I’ll be fine.”

 

            “Really, you can’t do this. With the new king…” The pleading was evident in her tone.

 

            The muscles of Alexandria’s back clenched, then released, as if a conscious decision had been reached. She whirled around and glared. “Who are you to tell me what I can and can’t do? You’re merely a slave a day in my confidence, and I’m a princess. Never forget that.” The train of her black gown cleared the floor behind her as she left, obviously annoyed.

 

            “I haven’t forgotten…” Lana murmured, a lithe hand reaching up to touch the golden collar encircling her neck. Her fingers traced over the figure engraved into it before another hand joined hers and grasped her fingers. “Who do we have more of an obligation toward?” she asked Mari solemnly. “Our charge or ourselves?” She looked out the large window on the edge of the room and sighed. Her tone was strangely discordant with her usual melody when she spoke next. “If we could only fly from here…”

 

            In the swift embrace that followed, she heard the answering whisper: “Ourselves and our charge are one with the proper goal in mind. Therefore we must take care of them both.”

They could see Alexandria leave with two men clothed in the dress of the townspeople… yet it was too artificial. Anyone could tell she was the princess, a fact reinforced further by the slight bows she received from whomever she passed.

 

            “Ready?”

 

            “Perfectly.”

 

            Mari threw the curtains shut on the room, engulfing them both in darkness. Their breathing identified their positions, and they clasped hands. “Relax,” Mari said in a lazy tone. Only the gold collar winked to show her presence before it too disappeared. Lana turned away to open the curtains again and peer down into the busy city below. She would leave momentarily, but first she had to trace a route to the ports…

As a lump of some sort of metal with odd drawings on it, it couldn’t have been described as ‘beautiful’ even by a blind man.

 

            “Isn’t it?” the vendor sighed, as if nostalgic. “One of the finest pieces I’ve ever made, if I do say so myself.”

“Those precious gems were collected from the richest king’s treasury in the Highlands,” he told her, referring to the tiny clumps of iron that clung haphazardly to it.

 

Alexandria tore her gaze free and looked at the vender without seeing him. “How much would you like for it?”

 

“Six gold pieces,” he said smoothly, his eyes gleaming.

 

“Done.” The princess reached into her change purse and dug out the six coins, dumping them in his hand. The vender looked about surreptitiously before closing his hand around the money. As he watched, the princess held the necklace reverently against her heart, then reached behind her hair to clasp it there. The odd piece of metal hung on the long chain languidly, resting in the valley between her breasts. All that could be seen of the strange ornament was the silver chain plunging into her gown and circling back up to her neck.

 

She appeared to shake her head and look about, confused. She smiled absently at him and meandered toward the other stalls, apparently unconcerned. Her guards followed, wary for pickpockets rather than hideous necklaces.

The first mate was marveling at its soft texture and the beauty before him when his he met the slave's eyes for the first time. Mari's golden gaze pierced his own, and he sank of his own will to the floor, still staring up at her with an open mouth. Then the man sagged sideways, eyes rolling back into his head as he hit the floor with a faint thump.

 

            “Thanks,” Mari told the slave-girl curtly as she stripped her. “This would be an embarrassing entrance otherwise.” She donned the girl's clothing, wrinkling her nose at the smell of the costume, relieved the unconscious sailor of his saber, and began descending a ladder that presumably led to the hold.

 

***

 

            Alexandria screamed again, her throat growing more hoarse with each repetition. She wriggled in her leather bonds and nearly fell face-first onto the wooden floor.

 

            “Shut up,” a man with a fierce-looking eye-patch hissed. His hand clenched and unclenched, muscles twitching in his cheek, but another voice interrupted his action.

 

            “You know what he said, Glyn.” The second man was entirely clothed in black leather, and his voice grated horribly, making both Alexandria and her captor wince. “Not a mark should be inflicted on her or the man pays himself.”

 

            “Wait until my uncle finds what you've done,” Alexandria said, her eyes piercing theirs smugly. “It won't take him long, and when he finds you--” Whatever else she was going to threaten was lost in the roar of laughter from the two men.

 

            The one named Glyn wiped the tears from his single eye and rubbed the skin around his eye-patch. “You don't get it, do you?”

 

            “What?” the princess demanded, but they were chuckling too fiercely to answer. “I order you, as subjects of this province, to tell me what-- you're laughing at,” she concluded weakly.

 

            Glyn's face painted the epitome of scorning disbelief. “You're joking.” The other man snorted and climbed a second ladder to the top deck. There was a moment as gears turned in the princess’s head to churn out a retort.

 

            Alexandria stuck out her chin in sheer frustration. “I am a princess. I never joke.”

 

            “Evidently you've forgotten this morning,” said Mari lazily from her seated position on a barrel. She had come down the first ladder into the hold with the silence of death.

 

            “Hey!” Glyn started forward with a knife in hand. “Who are you?”

 

            The woman adjusted the ill-fitting clothing on her frame and pointed to him with a saber. Glyn gulped. “Move.” The man scurried out of the way of the second ladder, muttering something under his breath that sounded suspiciously like a name. Mari's sword was at his throat in an instant, a blow landing on his wrist to disarm him. The knife spun wildly across the floor and embedded itself in a wooden pillar. “Repeat that.”

 

            “I'd get worse from the name!” he protested, gasping as the sword cut a line of red into his neck. It pressed deeper as Mari applied more pressure.

 

            “Don't think I won't,” She grinned, teeth bared to reveal two canine-like fangs in the front. “In fact, think that I will... your corpse fresh and bleeding before me. Oh?” she asked as the Glyn's eye widened and he shook his head slightly. The blade sliced further into his windpipe, and he moaned, blood dribbling from his mouth. ”You don't like the mention of your corpse fresh for draining?” The man's face was ashen grey with terror more than from the loss of blood. He was staring into her glittering, golden eyes. “Repeat the name and I might consider drinking from someone else.”

 

            In Alexandria's opinion, there really were better ways of getting information. Couldn't they have simply asked him under controlled torture about whatever stupid name it was later? And she really didn't understand the whole drain-the-corpse bit. What was Mari thinking? Alexandria glanced around for Lana, hoping she might be nearby, but she couldn't spot the blond anywhere.

 

            The true fear lurked not in Alexandria's sight, but in Glyn's mind. He gibbered in terror at the sight of blood seeping from Mari's mouth, whimpering as she licked at it with obvious delight. Her slave costume was no more; in its place lurked a vampire-esque cloak with a red hood. Glyn stared deeper into her eyes and realized they were not gold as he had thought before-- they were red, a deep blood-red ringed with the feral yellow tint that identified a vampire prepared to feed.

 

            “All right,” he cried raggedly at last, blood flowing easily from the wound and from his mouth. “My master is--” he choked, a clot of blood falling onto his vest.

 

            “Say it, curse you,” Mari growled, shaking him like a rag-doll. The poor man saw a vampire with its fangs bared and heard the howl break from its throat that promised all sorts of nasty actions with bodies, blood, and eternal pain--

 

            Glyn opened his mouth once more. “Hel--” His neck snapped suddenly to the side, and he screamed, the sound echoing around the small hold. He was most unfortunately limp in Mari's hand, and she dropped him to the floor, scowling. “Which Hell?” she muttered. There were too many names that started with that simple syllable.

           

            “What happened to him?” Alexandria asked, confused. Mari knelt beside her to untie her bonds. The princess craned her neck around her slave's form to see the body. “Oh, gods!-- You've killed him over a silly name.” She leveled a glare at her rescuer. “He deserved a trial.” She received an incredulous snort from Mari for her declaration.

 

            “For one, I didn't kill him,” the woman said with almost tangible ice. “His master did to conceal his name.”

           

            “What name?” Alexandria persisted.

 

            “That's what I was trying to find out,” Mari answered dryly. She had a sneaking suspicion, but she would have liked to confirm it. The princess beside her was silent for a minute as she stood and worked the circulation back into her wrists and ankles. When her slave began climbing the ladder back to the deck, Alexandria once again had to speak up.

 

            “Wait! What about the body? We can't just--”

 

            “Princess,” Mari grated through clenched teeth. She was obviously trying to keep her temper. “We must leave.”

 

            “But the body...” she protested weakly. A hand reached down and grabbed her by the back of her gown to hoist her to the deck. Sunlight blinded her, and she blinked, dazzled momentarily.

 

            Golden eyes peered into her own, and as she stared, fascinated, Mari said softly, “We will return to the castle immediately. You will lock yourself in your chambers with your closest handmaid and will not leave until Lana or I come for you. Is that clear?” Alexandria, well within the trance, nodded. “Then come.” The raven-haired girl jumped down from the ship, a hand steadying the princess so that she could land on her feet as well, and then the pair began the trip back to the castle.

 

***

Alexandria Peone gazed drearily out the window of her chamber. Then she looked round at the faces of the guards and groaned. For two weeks she had been stuck in this same room. Since the death of her father those fourteen days ago, a temporary ruler had been sent for—her father’s brother, technically her uncle. She had never met him, but it was whispered among the lower classes that he had dealings with the pirates.

 

            In fact, it was suspected by the people that pirates had been responsible for the king’s death. It could never be proven; the man arrested for the crime had been a mercenary, and they could be hired for anyone. He hadn’t even screamed the name under torture, though she had heard through her handmaid that they had kept him barely alive in case he changed his mind.

 

            Today held the meeting with Alexandria’s uncle. Just thinking about it made her wring her hands, a bad habit from her childhood that sometimes resurfaced under stress. Her handmaiden wordlessly handed her a goblet of clear, cold water, which she drank from for something to do. Poor Hattie was precisely as bored as she was, stuck in this tower room like the princesses of old.

 

            Far below, a crowd had gathered, first to mourn the passing of the king and then to demand the coronation of a new one. Alexandria, at the mere age of sixteen, was not deemed fit to rule by the laws of her people until she turned twenty.

 

            And she was rather glad at the moment that responsibility had passed over her fair head.

           

            The urgent yells of the crowd were becoming insistent, and the whole mass stirred restlessly. It was not something she should like to try to pacify.

 

            The door of the room opened, and every guard had his sword drawn in an instant. Alexandria spun to face the intruder, whoever he was, with her hand on the dagger hidden in her gown.

 

            “Lady!” a familiar voice cried, relaxing her. The face of the secretary of state peeked around the corner of the door, breaking into a smile. “Thank God you’re all right.”

           

            “I’m fine,” she answered as breezily as possible, trying to seem mature. “Has my uncle arrived yet?”

 

            “His ships have just passed into sight,” the secretary replied. “But I have come to announce another visitor. He is from Cathadral and seeks your hand in marriage.”

 

            Alexandria rolled her eyes in sheer exasperation. “Can’t he see I’m in mourning?” She indicated the inky blackness of her gown.

 

            The secretary smiled apologetically. “I suppose not, milady,” he answered gently. “We have checked him for any weapons. One guard will remain in the room, out of hearing.”

 

            “Thank you,” she answered, eyes drawn to the door where this mysterious man might appear.

 

            “May I announce,” the secretary proclaimed loudly, “the presence of noble Sir Greigan.” A tall, dark-haired man swept into the room, two female slaves following him, but Alexandria barely noticed them. Her gaze was fixed on the man who dared to confront her barely two weeks after her father had died.

 

            The guards withdrew, the secretary of state bowing his way out, and left one lone guard behind to stand respectfully by the door.

 

            “Lady Alexandria,” the man began. “I have come today—“

 

            Whatever speech he had prepared was cut off as a resounding slap snapped his head around. No doubt stars were twinkling in and out of his vision, but he could still see the princess glaring resolutely at him from a high-placed chair “How dare you come to propose not a fortnight after my father’s death. Have you no shame? No honor? Consider yourself rejected before you asked, rejected from birth, and indeed rejected from the castle!” One of the slaves’ eyebrows quirked as if she were amused.

 

            The guard started forward at her words to remove the man, but he waved a hand dazedly. “That was not my true purpose!” he tried to explain, swaying on his feet. “Please, princess, allow me to reveal the reason of my visit.” Alexandria halted the guard with a raised hand.

 

            “Allow him,” she spoke finally. “I have nothing better to do.”

 

            “I am here to present the gift of these two slaves,” he said in a steady voice, though he flinched when she rose out of her chair.

 

            “You must know—sir—“ she hissed with deliberate implication. “that while Limodia may consider slavery legal, the royal family and I do not approve of it.”

 

            “Allow me to explain further!” he cringed, attempting to bow his way into her favor. “Lady, these slaves, if you will, are quite special. They are no ordinary females. Please, I will demonstrate.” The two slaves rose at his gesture and came forward slowly. Alexandria reluctantly surveyed them, not without distaste.

 

            They were of identical height and facial structure, perhaps twins, but she could not determine their age. Despite their similar appearances, there were some marked differences that she observed with growing interest.

 

            The woman to the right supported herself on long, graceful legs that could be identified as pure muscle even through the thin linen of her breeches. Her hair was a rare color in the generally dark-haired population of Limodia: white-blond. What distinguished her even more were her light blue eyes; the people of Limodia on average sported brown or black. The woman’s mouth tugged up in a grin as she waited under Alexandria’s gaze, and she positively beamed up at the princess.

 

            Her counterpart on the left, however, was an entirely different matter. She would not blend well with a Limodian crowd either. The woman’s blue-black hair matched the population well enough, but the glittering intelligence in her golden eyes reminded Alexandria of a raven. Yet the intensity of the woman’s glance made the princess change her mind; she was more like a hawk than a raven.

 

            “This is Lana,” Their master indicated the fair-haired slave, who curtsied as well as she could in pants. “And this is Mari.” The darker girl simply glared before issuing the slightest of nods. It was an affront by the rules of the throne, but Alexandria was too fascinated to care.

 

            “And why have you brought them here?” she inquired. “As I have already told you—“

 

            “Yes, yes, princess,” the man cut her off, but that was too much even for her to ignore. “Begging your pardon,” he added hastily. “These girls and their service need not be from slavery. I have brought them as a gift of protection.”

 

            “Protection?” Alexandria asked, hardly able to keep the scorn out of her tone. She waved a hand at the guard in the corner, then at the door. “I am so protected I can barely stand it.”

 

            At this statement, the slave named Lana laughed merrily, the sound reverberating around the room and boosting Alexandria’s spirits substantially. Even Mari’s lips twitched. Their lord seemed to find it not the least amusing at all.

 

            “These guards can be slain, they can be tricked,” he said patiently. “These girls cannot.”

 

            “What do you mean? Anyone can be tricked eventually.”

 

            “These slaves are magic!” he insisted. “Accept them into your service and you will find you no longer need guards.”

 

            It was tempting. Alexandria was sick of the stony-faced men watching her every move, only leaving her to bathe and visit the toilet.

 

            “Very well,” she said at last. “Leave them and be gone from my sight.” She turned to ascend once more to her chair, sinking into it with a sigh.

 

            “One more thing…” the timid voice of the man ventured, and she clenched her eyes shut before relaxing to turn and face him.

 

            “Yes?”

 

            “The girls wear a pair of identical golden collars,” he whispered, bending so close to her that she could feel his breath. “You must never, ever, release them. I hand you the key.” Alexandria took it and slipped the light object into the sleeves of her gown, her mind brimming with questions.

 

            “I can release them whenever I so desire,” she declared coldly, but the man sank to one knee.

 

            “Please, princess,” he urged. “Promise me you will never release them. It would spell disaster for you, for the kingdom, and for all they have come in contact with.” He hesitated, then continued, “They are under a curse of a kind that is only in effect when they do not wear the collars.”

 

            “A curse?” she inquired. “Pray tell.”

 

            “Lady…” He drew even closer. “Do not take off the collars and you will never have to trouble yourself with it.”

 

            She pulled away from him and spoke, turning her back to him. “I do not want cursed slaves. If you will not tell me, I will not have them. Understood?” Alexandria waited for an affirmation and frowned when none was forthcoming. “Do you understand?” she repeated, turning. “I wish to know—“ She blinked.

 

            The lord was gone from the room, a slip of parchment was sitting on her chair declaring that she owned the two slaves standing before her, and the guard was lying unconscious near the door.

 

            “Bugger!” The word burst from her mouth in dismay.

 

            “I’m sorry, milady,” Lana said smoothly. “It seems he’s gone away.”

 

            “So it would seem,” Alexandria answered, turning to look out the window once more. The ships that the secretary of state had reported were docking in the ports, bells ringing to cheer their arrival.

 

            “Will we go to meet them, milady?” Lana inquired in her light voice.

 

            “Yes.” The princess grumbled, the color in her face disappearing. “Let’s get this over with.”

He was looking down at her from a great height.

 

    His brown eyes blinked rapidly as they adjusted to the darkness of her prison. It was in the ground, in a kind of time they could create where no time passed at all. If no time passed, she would never have time to escape. He barely understood the concept himself, but he didn’t have to in order to realize the fruitlessness of trying to trick it. The walls going down to the bottom were smooth stone and had no footholds, no handholds, no cracks of any kind.

 

    It scared him that it took this impossible prison and their full combined power to hold her here. He shook his head, not sure whether it was in frustration or amazement. She was not one of them, but her power was too incredible for her own kind. And look how she had abused it, abused the trust they had placed in her…

 

    She looked up as he descended the long distance down into the pit. “Lucas.” The greeting was cold and emotionless from her lips. He remembered a time when she would have warmly embraced him, whispering a private joke into his ear, laughing, before running off to begin some mischief or another. Now they both stood here in uncomfortable places: he, as part of the condemning, and she, as the condemned.

 

     If he had been in his true form, his tail would have drooped.

 

    She was in human form, like him, and Lucas could understand why Emstur, a mutual acquaintance, was so tempted, no, tormented by her. From the copper curls that framed her proud jaw to the hazel eyes that were sometimes green and sometimes brown, she was a goddess. And yet, while there was indeed something terrible about her beauty, she was not a goddess.

 

    “I assume you have decided my punishment?” Fury seeped into her previously icy tone, and he felt the air ripple around him. The power in the prison was tangible, and he knew through experience that his own was not much greater than hers.

 

    “The Voice has decided it,” he told her, unintentionally placing the blame elsewhere to avoid her accusing undertones. “Your punishment…” he hesitated, hating that the Voice had sent him to tell her. Cowards, he fumed, but he knew that wasn’t it. He was the messenger. This was his duty, to communicate between the gods and all other life that had been created by the One.

 

    She remained silent while he fought himself on what to tell her, how to tell her, how to tell his friend her fate… but there was no better way.

 

    “Your punishment,” he said, very softly. “is to have your soul split.”

 

    A delicate shudder ran along the lines of her body. Her eyes were a dull brown.

 

    “My soul?” she asked, a flicker of emotion entering her tone that he recognized faintly as fear. He had forgotten how young she was, even in comparison to him. Never had he seen the vulnerability she had just hinted to. “It’s not possible to split a soul… without…”

 

    “You are not being sent to the afterlife,” Lucas said firmly. “It was Emstur who created the collars that will—”

 

    “Collars?!” she shrieked suddenly, a thread of her built-up power escaping to twine with the note. It ended in a high-pitched screech that made Lucas’ hair stand on end. She sprang to her feet and clenched her fists, the tendons defined in her neck. “Am I a rebel dog to be tamed?” she roared, the pointed reference finding its correct path to Lucas, who flinched. “Am I a lion who obeys the chair? I will not submit to this… deprecating act.” Her power died down, back under control in her confidence that they could not do such a thing. Her face became ice once more, impassionate and calm. “Emstur was foolish to suggest it. I would never allow the Voice to do this.”

 

    Lucas turned away, hiding the grief in his eyes. Regret leaked into his throat, making it hard to speak the next two words: “You must.”

 

    Something in his tone caught her attention, made her more like a friend rather than a defiant prisoner resisting a guard. “I must?”

 

    He swallowed visibly, and her eyes narrowed. His power lifted him clear of the prison before he spoke.

 

    “They have Daniel.”

 

    Her screams were immediate, justified, and, worst to Lucas’ ears… defeated.
